name: Color.Gradient
comment:
# Gradient
@docs GradientStop, Gradient, Palette, linearGradient, linearGradientFromStops, CosineGradientSetting, cosineGradient

aliases.name: CosineGradientSetting
aliases.comment: parameters for calculate RGB values for cosine gradients

aliases.name: GradientStop
aliases.comment:
A color and a stop value that indicates where the color appears in a gradient.
 The stop value must be between `0` and `1`.

aliases.name: Palette
aliases.comment: Create a new gradient `Palette` from a given `Palette`, with a given size.

values.name: cosineGradient
values.comment:
Create a gradient based on the on an [idea by Iñigo Quílez](http://www.iquilezles.org/www/articles/palettes/palettes.htm)
   For an interactive example have a look at Karsten Schmidt's example from his [thi.ng library](http://dev.thi.ng/gradients/)
values.type: Color.Gradient.CosineGradientSetting -> Color.Gradient.CosineGradientSetting -> Color.Gradient.CosineGradientSetting -> Color.Gradient.CosineGradientSetting -> Int -> Color.Gradient.Palette

values.name: linearGradient
values.comment:
Create a new `Palette`  with gradient colors from a given `Palette`,
 with a given size.

    p1 : Palette
    p1 =
      [ rgb 200 0 200
      , rgb 0 100 100
      , rgb 100 0 0
      ]
    gradient RGB p1 5 -- [RGBA 200 0 200 1,RGBA 100 50 150 1,RGBA 0 100 100 1,RGBA 50 50 50 1,RGBA 100 0 0 1]

values.name: linearGradientFromStops
values.comment:
Create a new `Palette`  with gradient colors from a given `Gradient`,
 with a given size.

    g : Gradient
    g =
      [ (0, rgb 200 0 200)
      , (0.25, rgb 0 100 100)
      , (1, rgb 150 175 160)
      ]
    gradientFromStops RGB g 5 -- [RGBA 200 0 200 1,RGBA 0 100 100 1,RGBA 50 125 120 1,RGBA 100 150 140 1,RGBA 150 175 160 1]

name: Color.Interpolate

types.name: Space
types.comment: The color space that is used for the interpolation

values.name: interpolate
values.comment: Linear interpolation of two colors by a factor between `0` and `1`.

name: Color.Manipulate

values.name: darken
values.comment: Decrease the lightning of a color

values.name: desaturate
values.comment: Decrease the saturation of a color

values.name: fadeIn
values.comment: Increase the opacity of a color

values.name: fadeOut
values.comment: Decrease the opacity of a color

values.name: grayscale
values.comment: Convert the color to a greyscale version, aka set saturation to 0

values.name: lighten
values.comment: Increase the lightning of a color

values.name: mix
values.comment: Mixes two colors together.  This is the same as calling `weightedMix` with a weight of 0.5.

values.name: rotateHue
values.comment: Change the hue of a color. The angle value must be in degrees

values.name: saturate
values.comment: Increase the saturation of a color

values.name: scaleHsl
values.comment:
Fluidly scale saturation, lightness and alpha channel.

That means that lightening an already-light color with `scaleHsl` won’t change the lightness much, but lightening
a dark color by the same amount will change it more dramatically.

For example, the lightness of a color can be anywhere between 0 and 1.0. If `scaleHsl (0, 0.4, 0) color` is called,
the resulting color’s lightness will be 40% of the way between its original lightness and 1.0. If
`scaleHsl (0, -0.4, 0) color` is called instead, the lightness will be 40% of the way between the original
and 0.

The values of the supplied tuple scale saturation, lightness, and opacity, respectively, and have a valid range of
-1.0 to 1.0.

This function is inspired by the Sass function [scale-color](http://sass-lang.com/documentation/Sass/Script/Functions.html#scale_color-instance_method).

values.name: scaleRgb
values.comment:
Fluidly scale red, green, blue, and alpha channels.

That means that reddening a already-red color with `scaleRgb` won’t change the redness much, but reddening a color
with little or no red by the same amount will change it more dramatically.

For example, the redness of a color can be anywhere between 0 and 255. If `scaleRgb (0.4, 0, 0, 0) color` is called,
the resulting color’s redness will be 40% of the way between its original redness and 255. If
`scaleRgb (-0.4, 0, 0, 0) color` is called instead, the redness will be 40% of the way between the original
and 0.

The values of the supplied tuple scale red, green, blue, and alpha channels, respectively, and have a valid range of
-1.0 to 1.0.

This function is inspired by the Sass function [scale-color](http://sass-lang.com/documentation/Sass/Script/Functions.html#scale_color-instance_method).
values.type: ( Float, Float, Float, Float ) -> Color.Color -> Color.Color

values.name: weightedMix
values.comment:
Mixes two colors together.

This function takes the average of each of the RGB components, weighted by a provided value between 0 and 1.0. The
opacity of the colors is also considered when weighting the components.

The weight specifies the amount of the first color that should be included in the returned color. For example, a weight
of 0.5 means that half the first color and half the second color should be used. A weight of 0.25 means that a quarter
of the first color and three quarters of the second color should be used.

This function uses the same algorithm as the [mix](http://sass-lang.com/documentation/Sass/Script/Functions.html#mix-instance_method) function in Sass.

name: Color.Convert

values.name: colorToCssHsl
values.comment:
Converts a color to an css hsl string.

    colorToCssHsl (hsl 1 1 0.5) -- "hsl(1, 1, 0.5)"

values.name: colorToCssHsla
values.comment:
Converts a color to an css hsla string.

    colorToCssHsla (hsla 1 1 0.5 1) -- "hsla(56, 100%, 50%, 1)"

values.name: colorToCssRgb
values.comment:
Converts a color to an css rgb string.

    colorToCssRgb (rgb 255 0 0) -- "rgb(255, 0, 0)"

values.name: colorToCssRgba
values.comment:
Converts a color to an css rgba string.

    colorToCssRgba (rgba 255 0 0 0.5) -- "rgba(255, 0, 0, 0.5)"

values.name: colorToHex
values.comment:
Converts a color to a hexadecimal string.

    colorToHex (rgb 255 0 0) -- "#ff0000"

values.name: colorToLab
values.comment: Convert color to CIELAB- color space
values.type: Color.Color -> { l : Float, a : Float, b : Float }

values.name: hexToColor
values.comment:
Converts a string to `Maybe` of color.

    hexToColor "#ff0000" -- "Ok (RGB 255 0 0)"
    hexToColor "#f00" -- "Ok (RGB 255 0 0)"
    hexToColor "ff0000" -- "Ok (RGB 255 0 0)"
    hexToColor "f00" -- "Ok (RGB 255 0 0)"
    hexToColor "1234" -- "Err \"Parsing hex regex failed\""

values.name: labToColor
values.comment: Convert a color in CIELAB- color space to Elm `Color`
values.type: { l : Float, a : Float, b : Float } -> Color.Color

name: Color.Blending

values.name: colorBurn
values.comment:
Darkens the backdrop color to reflect the source color.
Painting with white produces no change.

values.name: colorDodge
values.comment:
Brightens the backdrop color to reflect the source color.
Painting with black produces no changes.

values.name: darken
values.comment: Selects the darker of the backdrop and source colors.

values.name: difference
values.comment: Subtracts the darker of the two constituent colors from the lighter color.

values.name: exclusion
values.comment:
Produces an effect similar to that of the Difference mode but lower in contrast.
Painting with white inverts the backdrop color; painting with black produces no change

values.name: hardlight
values.comment:
Multiplies or screens the colors, depending on the source color value.
The effect is similar to shining a harsh spotlight on the backdrop.

values.name: lighten
values.comment: Selects the lighter of the backdrop and source colors.

values.name: multiply
values.comment:
The source color is multiplied by the destination color and replaces the destination.

The resultant color is always at least as dark as either the source or destination color.
Multiplying any color with black results in black.
Multiplying any color with white preserves the original color.

values.name: overlay
values.comment: Multiplies or screens the colors, depending on the backdrop color value.

values.name: screen
values.comment:
Multiplies the complements of the backdrop and source color values,
 then complements the result.

values.name: softlight
values.comment:
Darkens or lightens the colors, depending on the source color value.
The effect is similar to shining a diffused spotlight on the backdrop.

name: Color.Accessibility

values.name: contrastRatio
values.comment:
Get the contrast ratio of two colors represented as a Float.

Formula based on:
https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG20/#contrast-ratiodef

    contrastRatio Color.black Color.white -- 21.0
    contrastRatio Color.blue Color.blue -- 1.0

values.name: luminance
values.comment:
Get the relative luminance of a color represented as a Float.

Formula based on:
https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG20/#relativeluminancedef

    luminance Color.black -- 0.0
    luminance Color.white -- 1.0

values.name: maximumContrast
values.comment:
Returns the color with the highest contrast to the base color.

    bgColor = Color.darkBlue
    textOptions = [ Color.white, Color.purple, Color.black ]

    maximumContrast bgColor textOptions -- Just Color.white
